docs.title: Demo MKDocs Site
docs.text: This site is built with the intention of determining the architecture of a documentation site with multiple source repositories.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This demo site takes advantage of Git Submodules to consolidate documentation under one "monolith" documentation site.

This is made possible by mkdocs-monorepo-plugin. The plugin allows for the nesting of multiple mkdocs sites under one "big" site.

  • Building out individual mkdocs sites for each repository gives us the flexibility of hosting them under the monorepo site, as demonstrated here, or as their own sites.
    • My current recommendation is to host under the monorepo site. This will consolidate all of our documentation into one domain. However, if we see performance issues down the line with features such as search, we can always piviot back to hosting sites individually.
  • The only cavoet with this is plugins from submodule sites don't propogate up to the main site. To ensure a plugin is used in the main site, it will need to be added to this repositories mkdocs.yml file.
    • This could be accomplished with some custom tooling, or just a manual addition to the file. It seems like plugins aren't updated too often, so this likely won't be a big point of friction.

docs.title: Integration
docs.text:
Integration of submodules introduces the question: How do we ensure the site stays up to date when a submodule's documentation content is changed?

  • Git Submodules reference individual commits.

docs.title: Deploying the Site
docs.text:
Deployment of the site should occur on two conditions:

  1. The main/deployment branch of the documentation site is updated.
  2. A submodule's documentation is updated.

This would result in two GitHub actions, one to deploy the site when the main branch is updated, one to update submodules.

docs.title: Updating Submodules
docs.text:
Git Submodules reference individual commits. Because of this, we need to have some sort of automation to ensure we are keeping this documentation up to date. My proposed solution is Git Webhooks.

There are many types of webhooks, however what we'd want to use is a Repository Webhook

For this, we configure the submodule repo (in this example DemoGraphQlDocumentation) using the following steps:

  1. Navigate to DemoGraphQlDocumentation -> Settings -> Webhooks
  2. Create a new Webhook.
  3. Configure payload to be the main documentations dispatch url, example being https://api.github.com/repos/cadereynoldson/demodocumentation/dispatches
    • Be sure to configure this to use content-type application/json
  4. Set the webhook to be triggered on push events.

docs.title: GraphQL API Home
docs.text: Demo GraphQL Documentation

docs.title: Generating the GraphQL Schema
docs.text:
To generate the updated GraphQL Schema, we can use GitHub actions to generate a New GraphQL Schema on one or two of the following scenarios: * On a push to a branch * On opening a new PR

The following GitHub action would look something like this. If desired, we can also add this to our existing dotnet.yml build.

The tool used to generate our GraphQL markdown is graphql-markdown on npm. 

name: Generate GraphQL Schema File

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - '*'
      - '!main'  # Exclude main branch if necessary (optional)

jobs: 
    generate-gql-md-schema:
        runs-on: ubuntu-latest
        if: ${{ github.actor != 'github-actions[bot]' }} # Skip if the push is from the GitHub actions bot

    steps:
        # Checkout our repo
        - name: Checkout repo
            uses: actions/checkout@v3

        # GraphQL markdown uses node, so setup node.js
        - name: Set up Node.js
            uses: actions/setup-node@v3
            with:
            node-version: '16'

        - name: Install graphql-markdown
            run: |
                npm install graphql-markdown --save-dev -g

        # Setup .NET
        - name: Setup .NET
            uses: actions/setup-dotnet@v2
            with:
                dotnet-version: 8.0.x
                source-url: https://nuget.pkg.github.com/AllenInstitute/index.json
            env:
                NUGET_AUTH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.AI_PACKAGES_TOKEN }}

        - name: Install dependencies
            run: |
                dotnet restore

        - name: Run service
            run: |
                dotnet run --project=src/ProjectName

        - name: Generate GraphQL Markdown Schema
            run: |
                graphql-markdown http://localhost:5000/graphql --update-file ./docs/schema.md --no-toc --title "Project Name Schema" 

        - name: Commit and Push Changes
            run: |
                git config --global user.name "github-actions[bot]"
                git config --global user.email "github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
                git add .
                git commit -m "Automatically generated file"
                git push origin HEAD

docs.title: Query
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description continent Continent code ID! continents [Continent!]! filter ContinentFilterInput countries [Country!]! filter CountryFilterInput country Country code ID! language Language code ID! languages [Language!]! filter LanguageFilterInput

docs.title: Continent
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description code ID! countries [Country!]! name String!

docs.title: Country
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description awsRegion String! capital String code ID! continent Continent! currencies [String!]! currency String emoji String! emojiU String! languages [Language!]! name String! lang String native String! phone String! phones [String!]! states [State!]! subdivisions [Subdivision!]!

docs.title: Language
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description code ID! name String! native String! rtl Boolean!

docs.title: State
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description code String country Country! name String!

docs.title: Subdivision
docs.text: Field Argument Type Description code ID! emoji String name String!

docs.title: ContinentFilterInput
docs.text: Field Type Description code StringQueryOperatorInput

docs.title: CountryFilterInput
docs.text: Field Type Description code StringQueryOperatorInput continent StringQueryOperatorInput currency StringQueryOperatorInput name StringQueryOperatorInput

docs.title: LanguageFilterInput
docs.text: Field Type Description code StringQueryOperatorInput

docs.title: StringQueryOperatorInput
docs.text: Field Type Description eq String in [String!] ne String nin [String!] regex String

docs.title: Boolean
docs.text: The Boolean scalar type represents true or false.

docs.title: Float
docs.text: The Float scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional values as specified by IEEE 754.

docs.title: ID
docs.text: The ID scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as "4") or integer (such as 4) input value will be accepted as an ID.

docs.title: Int
docs.text: The Int scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

docs.title: String
docs.text: The String scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

docs.title: Other Documentation
docs.text:
This is a page for other documentation, such as examples.

Here is an example of the countries Query: This query returns a list of Country 

query {
    country {
        awsRegion
        capital
        code
        continent
        currencies
        currency
        emoji
        languages
        namenative
        phone
        phonesstates
        subdivisions
    }
}

docs.title: Demo Python Documentation
docs.text:
We use reStructured text documentation style in our Python docstrings, otherwise known as sphinx. To specify mkdocstrings to use this parser we can either:

  • Specify in mkdocs.yml to use this parser globally (unless specified otherwise): 
    plugins:
- mkdocstrings:
    handlers:
    python:
        options:
            docstring_style: sphinx
  • Specify in docs/some_page.md: 
    ::: path.to.module
    options:
      docstring_style: sphinx

docs.title: ExampleModule
docs.text:
Example module, containing a few methods to demonstrate the use of mkdocstrings

Source code in DemoMkdocsPython/src/example_module/example_module.py 
class ExampleModule:
    """
    Example module, containing a few methods to demonstrate the use of mkdocstrings
    """

    def foo():
        """
        I pity the foo.
        """
        return None

    def bar(i: str):
        """
        This method does something.
        :param i: A string provided to the function.
        :returns: A list of strings.
        :rtype: List[str]
        """
        return ["hi", "documentation"]

docs.title: bar(i)
docs.text:
This method does something.
